notes.text: New Red Hat build of Keycloak 24.0.9 packages with security impact Important are available from the Customer Portal
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat build of Keycloak 24.0.9 is a standalone server, based on the Keycloak project, that provides authentication and standards-based single sign-on capabilities for web and mobile applications.

Security fixes:
* Sensitive Data Exposure in Keycloak Build Process (CVE-2024-10451)
* Keycloak Denial of Service (CVE-2024-10270)
* Keycloak path trasversal (CVE-2024-10492)
* Keycloak proxy header handling Denial-of-Service (DoS) vulnerability (CVE-2024-9666)
* Keycloak TLS passthrough (CVE-2024-10039)
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: Red Hat build of Keycloak 24.0.9 Update

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text:
A vulnerability was found in the Keycloak Server. The Keycloak Server is vulnerable to a denial of service (DoS) attack due to improper handling of proxy headers. When Keycloak is configured to accept incoming proxy headers, it may accept non-IP values, such as obfuscated identifiers, without proper validation. This issue can lead to costly DNS resolution operations, which an attacker could exploit to tie up IO threads and potentially cause a denial of service.
The attacker must have access to send requests to a Keycloak instance that is configured to accept proxy headers, specifically when reverse proxies do not overwrite incoming headers, and Keycloak is configured to trust these headers.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

vulnerabilities.title: org.keycloak/keycloak-quarkus-server: Keycloak proxy header handling Denial-of-Service (DoS) vulnerability

acknowledgments.summary: This issue was discovered by Red Hat.

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in Keycloak. Deployments of Keycloak with a reverse proxy not using pass-through termination of TLS, with mTLS enabled, are affected. This issue may allow an attacker on the local network to authenticate as any user or client that leverages mTLS as the authentication mechanism.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak-core: mTLS passthrough

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in the Keycloak-services package. If untrusted data is passed to the SearchQueryUtils method, it could lead to a denial of service (DoS) scenario by exhausting system resources due to a Regex complexity.

notes.text: A flaw was found in Keycloak. This issue occurs because sensitive runtime values, such as passwords, may be captured during the Keycloak build process and embedded as default values in bytecode, leading to unintended information disclosure. In Keycloak 26, sensitive data specified directly in environment variables during the build process is also stored as a default values, making it accessible during runtime. Indirect usage of environment variables for SPI options and Quarkus properties is also vulnerable due to unconditional expansion by PropertyMapper logic, capturing sensitive data as default values in all Keycloak versions up to 26.0.2.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

cwe.name: External Control of File Name or Path

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in Keycloak. A user with high privileges could read sensitive information from a Vault file that is not within the expected context. This attacker must have previous high access to the Keycloak server in order to perform resource creation, for example, an LDAP provider configuration and set up a Vault read file, which will only inform whether that file exists or not.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak-quarkus-server: Keycloak path trasversal
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat has evaluated this vulnerability. This issue only affects the keycloak-quarkus-server, which is present on the Red Hat Build of Keycloak. No other products are affected.
